login.title: Optimize and record your CI test runs with Cypress Cloud
login.content: When you configure Cypress to record tests to Cypress Cloud, you'll see data from your latest recorded runs in the Cypress app. This increased visibility into your test history allows you to debug your tests faster and more effectively, all within your local workflow.

createOrganization.title: Finish setting up Cypress Cloud
createOrganization.content: Join or create an organization in Cypress Cloud to access your projects and recorded test runs.

connectProject.title: Connect your project to Cypress Cloud
connectProject.content: Bring your recorded test results into your local development workflow to monitor, run, and fix tests all in the Cypress app.

record.title: Record your first run
record.content: Record a run to see your test results in Cypress Cloud. You can then optimize your test suite, debug failing and flaky tests, and integrate with your favorite tools.

ct.title: {0} component testing is available for this project
ct.content: You can now use Cypress to develop and test individual components without running your whole application. Generate the config in just a few clicks.

enableNotifications.title: Start debugging as soon as your first tests fail
enableNotifications.subtitle: Cypress can notify you about Cloud test runs for your branch.

header.title: End-to-end testing is not set up for this project
header.description: Try it out now, or {0} to learn more

body.title: What is end-to-end testing?
body.description: End-to-end tests are perfect for testing your entire application from a user's perspective. Visit any URL and test full user journeys across pages and domains.
body.listItem1: Test full user journeys across multiple pages using {0} to load up a web page for your test.
body.listItem2: Work with live API calls or mock them with {0} to test all possible states of your app.
body.listItem3: Use {0} to maintain consistent browser sessions in your tests, and work with features like cookies and local storage, all while keeping your tests properly isolated.

header.title: Component testing is not set up for this project
header.description: Try it out now, or {0} to learn more

body.title: What is Component Testing?
body.description: Cypress Component Testing is a technique for developers to write, test, and debug components in isolation without ever leaving the browser - and without having to run your entire application.
body.listItem1: Instead of visiting a page, use {0} to render your components directly in the browser.
body.listItem2: Test from a user's perspective with all the same Cypress commands that are available in end-to-end testing.
body.listItem3: To get started, you can generate the config for {0}, {1}, and {2} (and {3}!).

experiments.title: Experiments
experiments.description: If you'd like to try out new features that we're working on, you can enable beta features for your project by turning on the experimental features you'd like to try. {0}

experimentalCspAllowList.name: CSP Allow List
experimentalCspAllowList.description: Enables Cypress to selectively permit Content-Security-Policy and Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only header directives, including those that might otherwise block Cypress from running.

experimentalFetchPolyfill.name: Fetch polyfill
experimentalFetchPolyfill.description: Automatically replaces `window.fetch` with a polyfill that Cypress can spy on and stub. Note: `experimentalFetchPolyfill` has been deprecated in Cypress 6.0.0 and will be removed in a future release. Consider using [`cy.intercept()`](https://on.cypress.io/intercept) to intercept `fetch` requests instead.

experimentalInteractiveRunEvents.name: Interactive run events
experimentalInteractiveRunEvents.description: Allows listening to the [`before:run`](https://on.cypress.io/before-run), [`after:run`](https://on.cypress.io/after-run), [`before:spec`](https://on.cypress.io/before-spec), and [`after:spec`](https://on.cypress.io/after-spec) events in plugins during interactive mode.

experimentalModifyObstructiveThirdPartyC.name: Modify obstructive third party code
experimentalModifyObstructiveThirdPartyC.description: Applies `modifyObstructiveCode` to third party `.html` and `.js`, removes subresource integrity, and modifies the user agent in Electron.

experimentalStrategy.name: Retries Strategy
experimentalStrategy.description: Applies a strategy for test retries according to your "flake tolerance"; options are `detect-flake-but-always-fail` or `detect-flake-and-pass-on-threshold`.

experimentalOptions.name: Retries Strategy Options
experimentalOptions.description: Sets retries strategy-specific options like `maxRetries`, `passesRequired`, and `stopIfAnyPassed`.

experimentalSingleTabRunMode.name: Single tab run mode
experimentalSingleTabRunMode.description: Runs all component specs in a single tab, trading spec isolation for faster run mode execution.

experimentalJustInTimeCompile.name: Just-In-Time compiling
experimentalJustInTimeCompile.description: Enables Just-In-Time (JIT) compiling for component testing, which will only compile assets related to the spec before the spec is run. Currently supported for Vite and Webpack.

experimentalSourceRewriting.name: Source rewriting
experimentalSourceRewriting.description: Enables AST-based JS/HTML rewriting. This may fix issues caused by the existing regex-based JS/HTML replacement algorithm. See [#5273](https://github.com/cypress-io/cypress/issues/5273) for details.

experimentalStudio.name: Studio
experimentalStudio.description: Generate and save commands directly to your test suite by interacting with your app as an end user would.

experimentalWebKitSupport.name: WebKit Support
experimentalWebKitSupport.description: Adds support for testing in the WebKit browser engine used by Safari. See https://on.cypress.io/webkit-experiment for more information.

experimentalRunAllSpecs.name: Run All Specs
experimentalRunAllSpecs.description: Enables the "Run All Specs" UI feature, allowing the execution of multiple specs sequentially.

experimentalOriginDependencies.name: Origin Dependencies
experimentalOriginDependencies.description: Enables support for `Cypress.require()` for including dependencies within the `cy.origin()` callback.

experimentalMemoryManagement.name: Memory Management
experimentalMemoryManagement.description: Enables support for improved memory management within Chromium-based browsers.

experimentalSkipDomainInjection.name: Skip Domain Injection
experimentalSkipDomainInjection.description: Disables setting `document.domain` to the application's super domain on injection.

device.title: Device settings
device.description: Review the configuration settings currently in use for this device.

testingPreferences.description: Configure your testing environment with these flags

step1.description: Uncover high-risk failed and flaky tests in CI before they become a problem in production.

e2e.name: E2E Testing
e2e.description: Build and test the entire experience of your application from end-to-end to ensure each flow matches your expectations.

component.name: Component Testing
component.description: Build and test your components from your design system in isolation in order to ensure each state matches your expectations.

componentDisabled.description: To test your components you must {0} as an NPM dependency for this project.

renameAuto.title: We recommend automatically renaming your specs in this step
renameAuto.changedSpecFolder: We've changed the default spec folder from:
renameAuto.changedSpecExt: We've changed the default spec file extension from:
renameAuto.changedSpecPatternExplain: We've changed the default spec file extension to {0} in order to avoid conflicts with any existing testing frameworks.
renameAuto.optedOutMessage: You've opted not to rename your spec file extension. You may need to change your specPattern later so we can still find your spec files.
renameAuto.folderRenameMessage: You've opted not to rename your spec file extension, we'll only rename the folder

modal.title: Change the existing spec file extension
modal.warning: We recommend using the default extension to avoid inconsistencies, framework conflicts, and confusion with your team.
modal.line1: Cypress now supports the ability to create new spec files from within the UI for both E2E and component specs.
modal.line2: All new spec files created within Cypress will use the default pattern of:
modal.line3: We want to rename your existing specs so that they have a consistent filename pattern for both E2E and component testing.
modal.line4: All documentation and example code will be using:
modal.line5: We've changed the placement of component specs to be next to their source files (e.g. src/Button.jsx and src/Button.cy.jsx)
modal.line6: The new default pattern of {0} prevents targeting conflicts with other testing frameworks. (e.g. Jest)
modal.label: Choose from the following filename patterns:
modal.option2: Don't rename anything â€” keep what I have.
modal.optOutAdditional: I may need to change my {0} later if I don't use the recommended filename extension.

renameManual.title: We need you to move your component specs manually
renameManual.componentFolderRemoved: We've removed the {0} options from the Cypress config.
renameManual.addedSpecPattern: We've added a new {0} option in the Cypress config that tells us where to find your component specs.
renameManual.cannotAuto: We can't automatically migrate your existing component spec files. We recommend that you move the following component spec files next to your source component files (e.g. {0})
renameManual.ifSkipNote: If you skip this step, Cypress will still be able to find them, but any new specs that you create will automatically be created next to your component files.

renameSupport.title: We'll automatically rename your existing E2E support file in this step
renameSupport.serveDifferentTypes: We now serve different support files for E2E and Component Testing.
renameSupport.changedSupportFile: We've renamed the E2E support file from:

configFile.willConvert: We'll automatically create a new {jsFile} file and seed it with your options from your existing {jsonFile}.

setupComponent.line3: In a previous step, we renamed your component specs, but can't automatically migrate your existing component testing configuration.
setupComponent.line4: In the next screen, you'll be able to reconfigure component testing in a new guided configuration wizard.
